<p>Celebrating its 20th anniversary, the Ukrainian Film Club of Columbia University will screen the second installment of the new documentary series &quot;Culture vs. War.&quot; It is a collection of six documentary shorts united by one theme: how Ukrainian culture was transformed into a weapon to repel the brutal Russian aggression. events.title: Laughing All the Way to Freedom:Americanization of a Russian Emigre
events.location: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027	Marshall D. Shulman Seminar Room, 1219
events.description:
<p>Please join the Harriman Institute for a book talk by&nbsp;<strong>Emil Draitser</strong>. Moderated by&nbsp;<a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/mark-lipovetsky/"><strong>Mark Lipovetsky</strong></a>.</p>
<p>All immigrants of the world coming to America expect it to be like their home country&mdash;only better. What they rarely consider is that, like that of any other nation, America&rsquo;s DNA differs from that of their country. It may take a lifetime to adjust to the unfamiliar country&rsquo;s culture, mentality, and way of doing many things differently from the way they have known. It is especially true when immigrants come to America from a country based on different principles, in this case, collectivist Russia versus individualist America, with opposing political systems&mdash;the democratic American one and the totalitarian Soviet. A sequel to the author&rsquo;s autobiographical trilogy&mdash;Shush! Growing up Jewish under Stalin, In the Jaws of the Crocodile, and Farewell, Mama Odessa&mdash;this book is part mem&shy;oir and part cultural study about the challenges of immigration and American acculturation. With self-deprecating humor, the author, a former Soviet satirist who was punished for trespassing the boundaries of public criticism, recollects his growing pains as he overcame his indoctrinated upbringing in a totalitarian society to embrace America&rsquo;s defining values.</p>

events.location: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027	Room 1201
events.description: <p>Please join&nbsp;the Ukrainian Studies Program&nbsp;for a literary event with <strong>Yuliia Iliukha</strong>, a Ukrainian writer from Kharkiv, as she reads from her newly published collection of flash fiction,&nbsp;<em>My Women</em>, translated into English by Hanna Leliv and released by 128 Lit. This collection brings together forty stories&mdash;at times excruciatingly difficult yet deeply moving&mdash;about women confronted by the countless brutalities of war. It locates the voices and devastating experiences of those who have been silenced, those who have lost loved ones, those who have fought and persevered, and those who have broken down. Yuliia will be joined by her American publisher, Andrew Felsher, who will share insights into the challenges, significance, and joy of bringing international voices to English-speaking audiences.&nbsp;Moderated by <a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/mark-andryczyk/"><strong>Mark Andryczyk</strong></a>.</p>

events.title: Book Talk: The Collaborative Constitution by Aileen Kavanagh
events.location: Jerome Greene Hall, 435 W. 116 St., New York, NY 10027	101
events.description:
<p>Please join the Center for Constitutional Governance for a lunchtime discussion on <strong><a href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/collaborative-constitution/342757CF12983E9096F0FC3E588F55F4" target="_blank"><em>The Collaborative Constitution</em></a>&nbsp;</strong>with author&nbsp;<strong><a href="https://www.tcd.ie/law/people/kavana23" target="_blank">Aileen Kavanagh</a></strong> (Professor of Constitutional Governance, Trinity College Dublin) and moderator <strong><a href="https://www.law.columbia.edu/faculty/david-pozen" target="_blank">David Pozen</a></strong> (Charles Keller Beekman Professor of Law, Columbia Law School).&nbsp;</p>
<p>In <em>The Collaborative Constitution</em>,&nbsp;Aileen Kavanagh offers a fresh account of how we should protect rights in a democracy. Departing from leading theoretical accounts which present the courts and legislature as rivals for constitutional supremacy, Kavanagh argues that protecting rights is a collaborative enterprise between all three branches of government - the Executive, the legislature, and the courts. On a collaborative vision of constitutionalism, protecting rights is neither the solitary task of a Herculean super-judge, nor the dignified pronouncements of an enlightened legislature. Instead, it is a complex, dynamic, and collaborative endeavour, where each branch has a distinct but complementary role to play, whilst engaging with each other in a spirit of comity and mutual respect. Connecting constitutional theory with the practice of protecting rights in a democracy, this book offers an innovative understanding of the separation of powers, grounded in the values and virtues of constitutional collaboration.</p>

events.description: <p>One of the world&#39;s most renowned choral ensembles, The Sixteen makes its series debut with a stunning program pairing works by William Byrd and Arvo P&auml;rt.
